name.text: 37.1.3.1 Mean of a discrete probability distribution

questiontext.text:
Mean and variance of a discrete probability distribution

If an experiment is performed \(N\) times in which the \(n\) possible outcomes \(X=x_1,x_2,x_3,\dots ,x_n\) are observed with frequencies \(f_1,f_2,f_3,\dots ,f_n\) respectively, we know that the mean of the distribution of outcomes is given by

\[\displaystyle{\bar x =\dfrac{f_1x_1+f_2x_2+\ldots +f_nx_n}{f_1+f_2+\ldots +f_n} =\dfrac{\sum_{i=1}^n f_ix_i}{\sum_{i=1}^n f_i} =\dfrac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^n f_ix_i =\sum_{i=1}^n \left(\dfrac{f_i}{N}\right)x_i.}\]
(Note that \(\displaystyle{\sum_{i=1}^nf_i=f_1+f_2+\dots +f_n=N}\))

The quantity \(\dfrac{f_i}{N}\) is called the relative frequency of the observation \(x_i\). Relative frequencies may be thought of as akin to probabilities; informally we would say that the chance of observing the outcome \(x_i\) is \(\dfrac{f_i}{N}\). Formally, we consider what happens as the number of experiments becomes very large. In order to give meaning to the quantity \(\dfrac{f_i}{N}\) we consider the limit (if it exists) of the quantity \(\dfrac{f_i}{N}\) as \(N\rightarrow\infty\) . Essentially, we define the probability \(p_i\) as
\(\qquad p_i= \lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\dfrac{f_i}{N}\)

Replacing \(\dfrac{f_i}{N}\) with the probability \(p_i\) leads to the following definition of the mean or expectation of the discrete random variable \(X\).

Key Point

Let \(X\) be a random variable with values \(x_1,x_2,\ldots, x_n\). Let the probability that \(X\) takes the value \(x_i\) (i.e. \(\text{P}(X=x_i)\)) be denoted by \(p_i\). The mean or expected value or expectation of \(X\), which is written \(\text{E}(X)\) is defined as:

\[\displaystyle{\text{E}(X)=\sum_{i=1}^n x_i\ \text{P}(X=x_i)= p_1x_1+p_2x_2+\dots +p_nx_n}\]

The symbol \(\mu\) is sometimes used to denote \(\text{E}(X)\).


The expectation \(\text{E}(X)\) of \(X\) is the value of \(X\) which we expect on average. In a similar way we can write down the expected value of the function \(g(X)\) as \(\text{E}[g(X)]\), the value of \(g(X)\) we expect on average. We have
\[\displaystyle{\qquad \text{E}[g(X)]=\sum_i^ng(x_i)f(x_i).}\]

In particular if \(g(X)=X^2\), we obtain
\[\displaystyle{\qquad \text{E}[X^2]=\sum_i^nx_i^2f(x_i).}\]
